texts.shortText:
Belongs to the filefish family, which are characterized by a very compressed body, small projecting mouth and (usually) by a greatly enlarged fist spine on the dorsal fin, which can be locked into a upright position by a smaller second spine. The pelvic fin is also reduced to a tiny bony rudiment. Most species occur in more tropical waters and this is one of few extending into the Western Cape.
This species is easily recognized by its characteristic shape, and pale colour which bears irregular dark blotched along its sides, although the extend and darkness of these markings in variable. Males may have blue spots and dashes at the bases of the dorsal and anal fins.

Global: Widespread across western Indian Ocean from Somalia to False Bay.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
Found on sandy and rocky bottoms to a depth of about 18 m. Small juveniles may congregate under floating objects such as patches of Sargassum weed or jellyfish in the open ocean.
Details unknown for this species but filefish typically feed on a variety of benthic invertebrates.

Combination of compressed shape, distinctive dorsal spine and colour pattern unmistakable and the only filefish whose range extends into the colder waters of the South Western Cape (several other species found in warmer waters of east coast).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 334).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra, E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 446)

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 5 (p. 443).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 236).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 886).
